text: what did you think about this article
It's definitely really sad to read, considering everything they're all going through. What did you think?
I think it's super sad... they seem to never catch a break, always struggling.
I can't imagine just living in an area that is constantly being ravaged by hurricanes or earthquakes. I take my location for granted.

Me too.. I also can't imagine living in the poverty and such.. It's crazy to think that people still live like that sometimes.  The gap between first world countires and places like that is crazy to em

It also seems unnecessary for there to even be such a gap. With all of the wealthy countries out there, I hope Haiti gets the help it deserves, because we, and other countries, can certainly afford it.
Agreed... with how frivilous and unnessary our spending is, it's so sad that countries like that don't get more support or guidance.
It's disheartening, isn't it? Places have the ability, money, time, and knowledge, and still refuse to help.
It is so sad... Or even the millionaires/billionaires out there. I know some of them donate, but at some point, you can only spend so much money. Why not put it to use.
Yep, exactly. It's just very frustrating overall. I think it's hard for others because they don't understand until their houses are being swept away for torrential floods.
It is hard to fathom/process, it's hard for me to really imagine
Give it twenty more years, for the more compassionate people to come into leadership. I think we'll see a big difference.
I think that is a fair statement... the new generation seems more caring and compassionate and willing to help
I know it sounds cold, but the older generation either doesn't care, or doesn't want to understand. Trust me, we'll see some major change soon enough.
I totally agree... I know there are some out there that care, but the majority, and the ones in charge, really don't seem to
Well, it was really great talking to you. I can't think of anything else to say about the topic. goodbye
we don't have enough lines yet
I apologize, I thought we did! I'm obviously a winner at counting. Hurricane Matthew was two years ago, wasn't it?
Haha no worries, we should be there now. That sounds about right to me, crazy, time flies, seems like I was just hearing about it
I think I recall it spawning a second hurricane, too, but it calmed down before being too bad. Yeah, I was definitely a few lines off lol
I kinda remember that too...Well it has been great talking to you! bye :)
take care! goodbye
Do you think the people of Haiti will ever recover from the effects of these recent natural disasters?
I am not sure it is a quite poor area :(
Yes it is. The people there need a lot of help. What do you think are some of the best ways to get them the help they need
I think if the UN is able to get them the required funds that will help a lot.
I am inclined to disagree. More money is only a temporary solution. I think they need lasting change
Yes, I hear there is a lot of corruption there as well, that is also a problem. Money is short term
Yes corruption is a huge problem. I think the NGO's and the UN should focus more on teaching the Haitian people to help themselves and develop the country
Yes getting a better government is the best way to help any region. Most countries, do not absolutely need outside for every disaster
I don't think the US wants a ''better'' government. They want a government they can control or influence. Corruption helps with that agenda
Yes two things can be true at once though. They want a better government but also try to get power and control in the process.
Do you think the United States has a vested interest in a developed and autonomous Haiti? I don't think so
Yeah I would not count on it. So you think the change should come from within?
Yes. I think that is the only way to get lasting long term and meaningful change. We have to help them help themselves
Yes that is why I think giving them aid, with no strings attached, is a good way to do this.
I disagree. With all the corruption it would just be money wasted. We should control the funds and focus more on sending people and material

Yeah but you can not have it both ways, either we send money and get power and control, or we send it no strings attached. So I think there might have to be strings actually, as you reminded me of the corruption.
Some other questions would be how much money and how long would we have to be involved?
I think the article said the UN was looking to send $800 million. No more then ten years in my opinion
I think 10 years is a good figure. But it seems like any problems Haiti has are only made worse by natural disasters. And no one can stop those
Yes there will always be disasters. Until the core problem of the country is fixed, I think we will always have to be ready to help.
That might take a lot longer than 10 years. It might be a good idea if the UN established permanent or semi permanent facilitiesc
Yes I think if we could supply them advisers and disaster professionals they could greatly benefit
True, but who would want to go there long term? I know I wouldn't. It's so far away and so different
I probably would not. We would have to compensate those individuals well.
The compensation would have to be high to motivate the right people
Yeah but I think the fact they would be helping those in need, could also be a motivation
True but would it be enough to keep them from their friends and family for long durations?
Probably different for each person, I am optimistic though.
Yes I can see that. It has been nice chatting. We have to bring our conversation to a conclusion
Yes this has been enjoyable. bye
goodbye
What did you think about this article
this just made me so sad he was a great guy
It makes me sad too...
crazy how fast they were going
It is... seems so dangerous.
yeah i wonder if eventually they will discover drugs or alchol
I wouldn't be surprised... a "celebrity" like that, it seems like it'd be normal almost
True but man he was such a great guy with good morals guess you really never now people
That is true... It's hard to think about.. I hope there was no suffering for him. I hope it was quick as could be.
I agree probably upon impact hopefully
Yes I would hope... Did he have much family did it say?
his family mother was in cuba came to see him once at a game
Oh yah that's right... Poor lady. It must be hard with no real closure, so suddenly like that
and being so far away and speaking spanish its not easy to come here form cuba i wonder if the funeral will be in cuba
I would hope so for her sake, and I';m sure he has other family down there
yeah very true feel bad for his friends families two
Yah... his mom shouldn't have to deal with travelling to a new foreign country on top of her grieving
Im sure the team will take care alot of it they helped her get her visa and loved him
That's true I didn't think about that... I bet they will be good support for her
yeah that would be a great support for them
And I'm sure they'd like to get to know his mom more, now that he is not around. See where he came from kind og
oh yes agreed, this has been a great conversation!
It has been for me as well! goodbye :)
bye!
Hey how are you? Are you a baseball fan?
Hey there. I am not but i do feel really sorry for the player! You?
I am not a fan but yes such a tragedy. I can
I feel bad not only for him but his family as well
Exactly. He was so young too. I can't even fathom losing a son so young. Parents should never have to bury their children but you hear it happening almost every day these days.
Yeah accidents happen and you just never know what will happen. :(
Most definitely. It makes you just want to hug your loved ones because you never know what'll happen.
Yup, i try to live by the motto live everyday like it's your last but it's not easy to follow

No, it's really not. You take each day for granted. I am in a season of my life where I just keep wishing the days away and hoping time speeds up. But it's no way to live because you miss the small moments!
I totally agree. If you don't mind me asking , why are you hoping time speeds up?
Oh, nothing bad. Really good actually but I am 7 months pregnant and it's just not fun. haha So I just want it to be December already.
Oh wow, congrats to you!
Thank you much. It's a great thing but just exhausting as expected!
I can't even imagine! But back to the sotry, i hope the family is fine now.
Yes, that would be a hard loss. Unexpected deaths are obviously way harder.
True. I heard of KINDA a similar incident with a football player that got into an accident and lost his arm. It's all so terrible
Oh man. Especially when someone does it for a living, it's hard to have any sort of life altering injury. It definitely crushes their spirits.
For sure! It's very heartbreaking. Well it was nice talking to you! bye
goodbye.
What did you think about this article
I always think stories of foster kids are pretty sad.
I agree... it's such a bad system sometimes and it breaks my heart, cause they are kids
Of course the kids make matters worse with delinquency, but that's not unexpected behavior considering their experiences.

Agreed, I'm sure he would be less likely to do that if he  had grown up in more stable conditions. It seems a lot of times the foster care system puts them in a situation that is just as bad or worse then where they wer ebefore

Yes, although even in good situations it sometimes doesn't work.  I knew an adopted boy and girl who'd come from a very violent background.  They destroyed the adoptive family they were brought into.  The damage had already been done to them as people.
Oh that's so sad... My neighbors did foster care a lot, and they were a great family. but man some of the kids you could tell had been through some shit and they were so angry.
Yeah, bless the people who are willing to do that.  And I'm sure most have good intentions.  But it's definitely a tough situation for everyone.
Agreed, I'm sure it would put a strain on any family or couple, especially if the kids are a handful
At least there was something of a silver lining in this story.
for sure! I just wish he could have been helped out more in the process, or for it to be easier on him
Yes, although I'd also go back to the mother and say the problem starts there. The mother (and probably father) were the first to let the kids down.
Agreed.... I can't imagine being that kind of parent. i don't get people who are. But there seems to be so many
Yes, unfortunately.  It's very easy to have children but not so easy to raise them well.
For sure... But it should be worth it to raise them well, it's your responsibility for having kids
Absolutely, I agree.  I think if you have children you owe them that.  And most people resent their parents enough you'd think they'd try harder with their own kids.  But few do.
For sure... it seems everyone has parent problems, but then seem to end up parenting the same way
It's a strange phenomenon.  At least to me.  But we're often more creatures of habit and genetics and convenience than of thoughtful consideration and values.
That is a great way to phrase it... It's very interesting for sure. Especially when you have 18+years to change
Do you have any children?
I don't, but my husband and I are trying
Sounds fun.  I hope you're successful and you, your husband, and future children are all thankful for it.  I don't have kids and figure it's best for all parties involved that it stays that way.
thank you! haha my husband felt that way for a while... It's scary for  sure the thought of bringing another human into this world
Yes,it's certainly a big responsibility.  But I'm sure you'll do fine.
Thank you! I sure will try haha
Anyway, it's been nice chatting with you.  Hope you have a good day.  bye
bye
Hello, what did you think about the article?
I think it's sad that a kid would have to go through all that...
It's terrible! I feel so bad for the kid because he should be in school.
Agreed, he should just be allowed to be a kid and not have to deal with all that
He probably was terrified and is going to be scarred for life now..
Oh yah, he'll definitly have the trauma of it all to deal with the rest of his life
Do you think jail can really change the kid for the better?
I think he needs therapy and guidance and  a stable home more so than punishment/jail
I agree. I have a cousin that went to jail before for stealing and he's the same.
Childhood tramua?
Pretty much. He just hasn't improved for the better and jail didn't really help him
Yah and I bet that is the case for a lot of people... how sad
The kid should be out making friends and playing video games.. not rotting in jail
I agree... It's so sad because he has already missed out on so so much of his childhood, and had it be horrible, and now this. He just needs a break and someone who actually cares about him
Hopefully he finds a girl he can marry that cares about him because his family doesnt
I hope so too, and that he is able to hold a healthy relationship
It just makes you wonder how many other children are out there being put in cells..
Probably way too many
Agreed. Well it was nice talking to you! bye
you as well, bye
I didn't know that coal mining had such adverse effects on the environment. No wonder everyone wants green energy so badly...
I feel bad for the people and the wild life.
Yeah for sure. The people are going to get all sorts of health problems and the animals are so desperate for food that they are attacking humans.
I can not believe how little they said they are going to pay the people for lost of land.
Yeah, it did seem little but Indians don't really make much money daily, compared to western countries.
That is true. I wonder what other animals besides the elephants are effected?
I imagine it's every animal in the surroundings. It's just that only elephants are big and strong enough to do something about it.
It has to be really bad growing up next to the coal mine with the bad air quality.
Yeah and the lack of water too. They spoke about their wells drying up.
Nothing seemed to be very regulated.
Maybe it's a matter of corruption? Since the officials didn't even make good on their promises regarding money for the land and work for one of the landowners sons.
Corruption and greed, but that is not just in India.
True, so many other places mine coal still though, including America. Do you think our coal mines are this bad?
No, not as bad because of regulations, but I would not want to live next to one.
That's true, I wonder what regulations can do to prevent all the ash though?
The way the coal in mined.
That's good. One of the worst parts of that article was reading about the white ash covering everything. Reading about it might've been enough to give me cancer.
Yeah, the woman losing her son was bad too.
Yup. Do you think this article is old or basically present day?
Sadly, I think it present day.
That's sad. I've read recently that India has started more recycling and other measures to take care of the enviroment.
India is a big country. So it probably has good parts when it comes to environmental protections.
Yeah, it's likely the cities that will start with the new reforms.
The story was about capitalism as much it was about environmentalism
True. Squeeze all the money you can out of the land without caring about the people, animals or general environment until it's too late.
You asked about mines in America. I believe this is how they were in the 1800s
Yeah and it was probably children working in there too.
many people died because of black lung.
It's a terrible way to die too. So much suffering. I wonder if the mine workers in India are suffering from that too?
I would think that they are.
It was nice talking to you about this unfortunate topic. Have a great day!
You have a great day too.

yeah the government should do something, it is ridiculous

yes all this just to turn a profit, with no regard for lives

no, I could not, can yuo?
No... it would eat me alive
same here, I could not function

yes or totally depraved

karma will catch up to them I think
I hope so..... They deserve it
I hope so too.  This has been a good talk goodbye
bye
Hey there, this article is pretty morbid. It really hits home for me though since I've dealt with this subject before.
Yeah, I thought it was very troubling because of the number of times she went for help, and she was always just turned away, essentially.
Yea suicide is no joke. It took me a couple of years before I received the help I needed and still it was a struggle. I feel so bad that this poor woman didn't get help. It's really messed up.

That's really sad to hear that it took that long. I'm not surprised at all, but it's ridiculous that mental health issues aren't treated as seriously as other medical issues since they can be just as fatal.
Exactly. Plus it really really hurts when people like, look at you as less of a person for having these issues.

Yeah, there is definitely an incredible stigma around it, treated as a weakness rather than a health issue. Can see that in this article too, a constant attitude of "you're all right, go home." Until the worst happens, then they act surprised.
I always hated it when people told me that. Especially family members. Never had a doctor say that though. Must've been so so rough for this woman.

Yeah, if you can't get help from doctors, who can you get help from? I definitely have heard stories like this before though, since mental health care is so overstressed and understaffed, people who aren't considered 'in immediate danger' just get sent home.

It's a shame and just messed up. I can't imagine the extent of the dread she felt. Like I've been there, but for so many repeated attempts to get help, just to be turned away.. that'll mess you up so much more.
Right, because I imagine she felt hopeless or unimportant. I guess the question is how things can be improved in the mental health care system?

Honestly, the first step is that people just need to take these things seriously. And insurance companies need to start covering treatments. It took me forever to find a decent psych. And of course insurance doesn't cover it. It's messed up. It all comes down to money these days I think.

Yeah, I think it would take a generational change, like starting with education in schools about mental health care and that it's just like any other illness that needs to be respected and understood.
For sure. Through my experience I find that it is older people that are the most..uh.. skeptical when it comes to topics/illnesses like these.

Yeah, they were raised with a "suck it up" attitude and people with more severe mental illness were hidden away or sent away. I don't know how much can be done about people like them, would be best to focus efforts on the young and then try to change society from the bottom.
Oh man the amount of times I heard "suck it up" or " you have no reason to be depressed." That messed me up bad.
I'm sorry that happened to you. It's so ignorant. We definitely need education campaigns and PSAs to try and educate people.

For sure. It's kinda messed up when your own family is ignorant to your blatantly obvious issues. Which ties back into that article. I can't even inagine what it feels like for a doctor to just tell you to get over it. That's like going to the police to report a major crime and they just say "deal with it yourself."
Yeah I feel like that whole system needs a massive overhaul. Like that's their government system so they need to be extra accountable over there.

Yea and you'd think that they would be. But of course healthcare takes a backseat to like idk.. butter knife licenses or something pointless. On a side note though.. drowning in the ocean must be one of the worst ways to go. Like thats prolonged panic and suffering before lights out. Legit sounds absolutely horrible.
Yeah, she took one of the worst ways out. She must have been desperate.

For sure. You have to be really desperate to put yourself through that. I'm glad I never hit that point; I'd rather it be quick if it was gonna happen. But lord, that woman's death was so needless. It did not need to happen and the fact that help was refused is so disgusting. I wonder if those doctors even felt remorse about it.
I feel like it probably happens a lot so they might be numb to it.
Ah yea they probably deal with death all the time. Didn't think about that.
It's something that needs to be investigated by people above them though, like by politicians etc, they need new directives to properly handle things.
For real. But will they actually do anything is the real question. I'm not sure if half of them take mental issues seriously either.

I wonder if in that particular case, in the UK, if it will help that it was someone involved with the news media. Like it might make the media pay more attention to it and they'll get more pressure because of that.
That is a good point. Sometimes it does take a tragedy from someone famous to get the ball rolling. Kinda sad that it does take that though to be honest.
Yep, I feel like that's typical though, and we just need to work with it.
As with most things in our lives I suppose.
Yeah. If the media puts pressure, that might actually cause some change, even if it's sad that that is what it takes. It's better than nothing. Could be the start of a good education campaign.

And honestly that is what we need. Just some good education to get people to realize that this stuff is serious. Well anyway, it's been a lovely chat with you Random Turker. Here's hoping the rest of the work day goes smoothly :)
For sure. Have a good rest of your day. :)
bye
goodbye

Hey there! So this article is something. I can't help but wonder why people of different religious backgrounds can't seem to get along in that part of the world. We seem to do ok over here in the West.
Hello! To a certain extent. I mean, the recent attacks on synagogues and widespread prejudice against Muslims here in the west doesn't seem to be too far removed.

Good point. Maybe I am a bit biased in this. I am not a very religious person. Personally I think it causes more problems in the world. Too many violent acts in the name of God, or Allah, etc. The needless loss of life is quite saddening.
I agree and am on the same page when it comes to religiosity. It seems like these militant groups in the Middle East are sincerely devoted to unmaking thousands of years of human progress.

Yea. I don't understand it personally. I guess their religion demands them to kill? Or maybe people in power have just twisted it into that meaning. It's just a shame though that people are being persecuted for their beliefs. What does it matter if someone else worships a different being than you? How does that effect you?

From what I understand about these groups is that they have decided to pervert their sacred texts in their interpretation so that they are in fact called to violence. An analog would be the Westboro Baptist church here in the states. If someone is not following the same religious tenets as you it makes them much more difficult to control; you aren't playing by the same rules.

Of course it comes down to control. I hate that people ar elike that to eachother tho. But of course I suppose it is in our nature to try to be dominant over eachother. Also as for Westboro, those people disgust me. Absolute degenerates full of hatred.

Hatred can be a very powerful force. Unfortunately, it seems that our world is filled with more of it every day; or at least those who are full of hatred have the loudest voices. I'd like to think that these militants truly believe that they are saving peoples souls, but the fact that they would allow them to stay as long as they paid a tax kind of robs the whole process of any mystique. This whole thing is about power. I agree about any self righteous group too. Can't you find something that is actually productive to do with your time?

I just hate that so many people need to suffer. It isn't right, no matter the reason, to persecute and murder people. And using religious views as a cover isn't an excuse. It also doesn't help that entire part of the world is so volitile in general. Hasn't there been conflict there for literal centuries?

Exactly, and that conflict prevents them from making any marked social or political progress at the lower levels of society. The rich get richer and the poor are left to fight each other over the scraps that remain. Plus, in a lot of ways America specifically has been spurning on this conflict for it's own vested interest in arms sales.
Don't forget the oil as well. We gotta chug that sweet sweet crude at the expense of our own soldiers lives, and the natives lives. It's a vicious cycle of greed, and power

Right, it's a crying shame. I have a very difficult time attempting to put myself in the shoes of the people who are affected by these types of problems. I mean, waking up in the middle of the night to your family being slaughtered or sold into slavery and being told to just deal with it?
And the trauma of war in general as well. Always living in fear of weather or not you are going to get bombed, shot, raped, etc. I'm sure that there is an immense amount of suffering in that region.
It's insane. The question is, what can we in the west even do to help? Is there anything at all?
Well the only thing we can do is use military, but that in and of itself is a bad thing because then they hate us even more.

I think that it would depend on the approach. I've heard there has been some success in the US forces training a standing army in Afghanistan, but not much. I was thinking more about humanitarian efforts.
Hmm. Not sure what we could do in that regard. I don't think they'll listen to the UN. Ugh it's just a complicated situation.

Yes, and after having this conversation definitely something I need to get more information on. I don't know about you but i've only about ten minutes left on my HIT timer, so why don't we wrap this up relatively quickly?
Same here.
So, do you hail from the states?
Indeed I do. Right in the bible belt.
Ha! Me too.
Yea. Thats why when you mentioned Westboro I immediately was like. Ew.
I've just seen them mentioned in mainstream media on occasion. Do you usually keep up with new?
Yea most of the time. People around here hate that group. They picketed at a marines funeral here once.
I actually heard about that. Totally shameful. Do you have family in the military?
Yes I do.
My younger brother is currently serving in the army.
My Uncle is in the Marines haha. Anyway, It's been a lovely conversation with you random turker. Have a great rest of the work day c:
Back at you!
bye
bye
I felt very disturbed while reading the article about the family situations.
Yeah for sure...Do you think you personally would return to Mosul if you were a Christian?
It's a hard question.  I feel obligated to return, but it's so dangerous.
I agree, there would be a longing to fix the area and to prevent a similar disaster from happening again.
Right, the whole town needs built again and the entire city is hurting from all the struggling. It would also be so hard to do alone. Would need a team that could agree.
I don't even think they have the powers or the numbers to fix anything. They were a minority before all the bloodshed and they are losing members every day.
Yeah, that's why no one could do it alone. I'd hope there would be a few strong willed individuals that may be able to start something and train others
It's a little like solving racism. What are the Christians really supposed to do? Tell the fanatical Muslims to not kill them because of their religion?
Which will never work. They'll do what they want and have been doing. Basically an army needs created, but they don't have the tools for that.
An army for what? Like an Israel vs the middle east situation? Where they basically stockpile weapons and a serious war could break out at any time.
Not that drastic hopefully. Something more of a union maybe, versus army. The few that can defend land or people from Muslims. But I agree, not a major force.
I think the internet is the only way to solve it. Once people talk to the other side and see they are just people like everyone else.
I'm not sure. The internet and possibly media may not work beneficially.

The way I see it, is growing up their family and friends are constantly pounding into their heads, "hate the west." Then they go on a computer and play video games with American or European people and see that they aren't so bad. There's no reason to hate these people.
I can see that. But how is that going to get fixed. It's the elders opinion that would need to change.
Yeah, once people are set in their ways, there's no changing their prejudices. You basically have to wait for the older people to die off...
It's a shame. They are hurting their own people instead of being able to move forward away from this crisis.
Also I think it's only a small fraction of the fanatical Muslims that are to blame.
Granted, that may be true. But that small fraction on both sides is hindering the whole situation.
Yup. Anyway, it was really nice of France to welcome Christians that feared going back to Mosul.
Oh of course. Maybe France could send some ally's back with them to help regrow.
I doubt that any French people would volunteer for that...
There's not exactly much hope there. But if some of the Christians have been able to become close to the French, it may be a start.
Yeah. Do you think America took in a lot of asylum seekers from this tragedy?
No, sadly America's own political stragedy prohibits too much outside assistance for that.
I think they have a lottery for Christians from Middle Eastern countries.
Some are allowed to come, but not nearly the amount that actually need help and assistance.
Yeah but the amount of people that need help and assistance is far more people than we can handle. That's millions of people!
Agreed completely! America can't do that. I'm not on board with the complete denial. I think petitions are needed to keep the process flowing.
Yeah, that makes sense. I hope in the next couple of generations the tension in the Middle East will finally be released.
goodbye

I never thought about the painful memories keeping people from returning.
Do you mean to like their homeland?
Yes, after wars and what they have seen.
Yah.. I never really thought about it either but it makes total sense
How long before the middle east is put back together, I don't think it will be in our lifetime.
I agree... which is sad to think about. How long will those peopel continue to suffer? and the people trying to help suffering as well
Yeah it is very sad
and it could be fixed! There is the funds out there in the world, and the know how.
I agree with that
These stories just make me think/realize the massive gap that there is in the world
These stories are very sad and make me thankful for my life.
For sure, it reminds me to take a step back and just be grateful for what I have
Totally
and the people who go to help, I'm sure they will struggle with what they saw/did etc for the rest of their life...
I would be. To be told to convert or die is the ultimate test of faith.
Yes and they shouldn't have to make that kkind of choice over faith.. it's silly
Very silly to us, but some people do take their faith as life or death.
Yes, which is their choice I guess
I believe, but I don't fault others for believing different from me.
I don't either, everyone is entitled to their own opinion
It was very nice chatting with you! bye

Hi; I thought the article was pretty accurate.
I can relate to them in some ways I think
I can't even imagine what it would be like to be at war, or in the services in general.
mental illness is horrible and they deserve help
I agree. We should take better care of our servicemen and women.
They have done so much for us we owe it to them
We should also not enter needless wars and send them away unnecessarily. It's too common.
Its all about money, it creates money so it will continue to happen
They're just pawns in a big political game.
It all needs to stop but we both know it will not
Agreed. I don't believe they're really "defending our freedom" and I wish young kids would stop joining for the recognition.
Do you believe that's what it is? I think these young kids are tricked into joining
That, too. And bribed- crazy amounts of money, travel, free education...
They have no idea what they are fighting for, they are dying for a country that does not care about them
100%. I can't imagine just following someone else's orders blindly.
